Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "API push gives connection closed when error message has new lines in it" (#6279) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This line can cause ASP.NET to close the connection (not even HTTP 500) when the reason phrase has new lines in it.

```
> nuget.exe  push "C:\Users\jver\Downloads\nuget.packagemanagement.powershellcmdlets.1.0.0-pre-20150120222735.nupkg"  -source https://localhost/api/v2/package -apikey API_KEY
Pushing nuget.packagemanagement.powershellcmdlets.1.0.0-pre-20150120222735.nupkg to 'https://localhost/api/v2/package'...
  PUT https://localhost/api/v2/package/
An error was encountered when fetching 'PUT https://localhost/api/v2/package/'. The request will now be retried.
An error occurred while sending the request.
  The underlying connection was closed: An unexpected error occurred on a receive.
  Unable to read data from the transport connection: An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host.
  An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host
  PUT https://localhost/api/v2/package/
An error was encountered when fetching 'PUT https://localhost/api/v2/package/'. The request will now be retried.
An error occurred while sending the request.
  The underlying connection was closed: An unexpected error occurred on a receive.
  Unable to read data from the transport connection: An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host.
  An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host
  PUT https://localhost/api/v2/package/
The underlying connection was closed: An unexpected error occurred on a receive.
  Unable to read data from the transport connection: An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host.
  An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host
```

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/e60e75fcab128094aa8aa0410a17ffc57bddf4bd/src/NuGetGallery/Controllers/ApiController.cs#L659-L667

I would recommend only showing the first line or collapsing multiple lines to one,

```csharp
var m = string.Join(" ", packagePolicyResult
    .ErrorMessage
    .Split('\n')
    .Select(x => x.Trim()));
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Don't require SmtpUri" (#6278) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "Don't require SmtpUri" (#6278) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "[Test Failure] PackageReference Migrator menu was enabled incorrectly to all projects include C++ and .NET Core" (#7176) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev 5.0.0.5381
VS Version: D16.0stg 28002.3001
OS Version: Windows 10 RS4_Release 17134.1.180410-1804
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Create a C++ UWP template via VS.
2. Open PM UI of the project by right-clicking the project->Manage NuGet Packages… in Solution Explorer.
3. Install a package (e.g. “SampleCPlusPlusDevicePackage”) with “Packages.config” format.
4. Right-Click the “References” node or “packages.config” file.
## Expected
There should be no PackageReference Migrator menu since it not support for C++ project. 
## Actual
There is PackageReference Migrator menu showing and the “eligible for migration” warning dialog pop out after clicking the menu as below screenshot. 
![migratorenabledtoallprojects](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/43763866-692a6eea-9a1b-11e8-9a22-2fb2cd9493e7.png)

## Note
1.It repro on .NET Core projects which are already PackageReference.
2.It repro on D16.0stg 28002.3000+NuGet Client Dev 5.0.0.5375.
3.It didn't repro on D15.8 28002.00+NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-RTM\4.8.0.5377.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Is there a way to manage allowedVersions across all projects in a solution?" (#7181) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: I want to limit a set of packages to stay below a specific version number for every project in a solution. Is there a way to do that?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nuget package update reformats config files poorly or creates unwanted config files" (#7180) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The [VS Feedback item](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/182303/nuget-package-update-reformats-config-files-poorly.html) has the original unredacted attachment illustrating the problem.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15381181/43792564-1316de9a-9a47-11e8-8a2f-087223997ff4.png)
In this redacted example, you can see its removed the line breaks as well as changed the spacing before the closing element. Its changing the formatting of config files in this manner for projects that are not having any binding redirects added or changed, and for projects that aren't being targeted for the package update.  

Its also creating new app.config files for projects that didnt have them and don't need them (class libraries).

All of these are a tedious venture to cleanup before checkin or submitting for code review. On larger solutions (> 50 projects) this can easily take an hour or more to clean up - every time a single package is updated in a project in the solution.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget.exe returns exit code zero for invalid arguments" (#7178) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used: nuget.exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.7.0.5148

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):

```
C:\>ver
Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.16299.492]
```

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

Calling nuget.exe with invalid command line arguments shows the help text for the command, but terminates with a zero exit code which makes it difficult to catch errors when calling nuget.exe from a script.

For example, when using the "-version" parameter (but not supplying a value):

```
C:\>"C:\Program Files\nuget\nuget.4.7.0.5148.exe" install mypackage -version -outputdirectory "C:\temp\packages"
install: invalid arguments.
usage: NuGet install packageId|pathToPackagesConfig [options]
... etc ...

C:\> echo %errorlevel%
0
```
I think this is because this line just falls through to "return 0" at the bottom of MainCore():

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/8e9a585d86f583e0c1e07cd7f389ace865b9ac60/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.CommandLine/Program.cs#L132

My expectation would be that invalid command line arguments should return a non-zero exit code. 

Maybe add a "return 1" after the above call to ViewHelpForCommand? I can send a PR if that helps?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Contradicting error/warning messages in nuget pack" (#7177) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet.exe 

NuGet version 4.6.2.5055, 4.7.0.5148 and 4.8.0.5278

## Description

I run a powershell script on TFS build to pack my nuget packages like this:
`& $nugetExe pack $fullName -BasePath $outputDirectory -OutputDirectory $outputDirectory -IncludeReferencedProjects -Verbosity detailed;`

`$fullName` specifies my .csproj file.
(FYI: I only want to pack .csproj-files which have a corresponding .nuspec file.)
The corresponding .nuspec file locks like this
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2010/07/nuspec.xsd">
	<metadata>
		<id>$TargetName$</id>
		<version>$version$</version>
		<title>$TargetName$</title>
		<authors>$author$</authors>
		<requireLicenseAcceptance>false</requireLicenseAcceptance>
		<description>$description$</description>
		<summary>$TargetName$</summary>
		<tags>$TargetName$</tags>
	</metadata>
	<files>
		<!-- .NET 4.6.2 -->
		<!--<file src="$OutputPath$$TargetName$.dll" target="lib\net462" />-->
		<!--<file src="$OutputPath$$TargetName$.xml" target="lib\net462" />-->
		<file src="$OutputPath$$TargetName$.pdb" target="lib\net462" />

		<!-- .NET 4.0 -->
		<file src="$OutputPath$net40\$TargetName$.dll" target="lib\net40" />
		<file src="$OutputPath$net40\$TargetName$.xml" target="lib\net40" />
		<file src="$OutputPath$net40\$TargetName$.pdb" target="lib\net40" />
	</files>
</package>
```

## Issue
My issues is with the IMHO misleading error messages (see logs):
```
...
Error NU5118: File 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\net40\MyPackage.dll' is not added because the package already contains file 'lib\net462\MyPackage.dll'
Error NU5118: File 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\net40\MyPackage.xml' is not added because the package already contains file 'lib\net462\MyPackage.xml'
...
```
Even if there already is a file with the same name. Those do not have the same source or target path. (Furthermore adding more than one assembly with same name but for a different framework should be very common.)

A little down the line it states:
```
...
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.dll'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.pdb'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.xml'.
...
```
So the file have been added and therefore contradicting the earlier message.

### Verbose Logs

#### 4.6.2.5055
4.6.* There were only warnings but still contradictory:
```
NuGet Version: 4.6.2.5055
Attempting to build package from 'MyPackage.csproj'.
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '15.7.180.61344' from 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Enterprise\MSBuild\15.0\bin'. Use option -MSBuildVersion to force nuget to use a specific version of MSBuild.
Packing files from 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin'.
Using 'MyPackage.nuspec' for metadata.
WARNING: File 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\net40\MyPackage.dll' is not added because the package already contains file 'lib\net462\MyPackage.dll'
WARNING: File 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\net40\MyPackage.xml' is not added because the package already contains file 'lib\net462\MyPackage.xml'

Id: MyPackage
Version: 1.5.11589-Dev
Authors: SomeOne
Description: The common logging component.
Tags: MyPackage
Dependencies: 

Added file '[Content_Types].xml'.
Added file '_rels/.rels'.
Added file 'MyPackage.nuspec'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.dll'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.pdb'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.xml'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.dll'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.pdb'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.xml'.
Added file 'package/services/metadata/core-properties/970164baddbf437393604ddc23824814.psmdcp'.

Successfully created package 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\MyPackage.1.5.11589-Dev.nupkg'.
```

#### 4.7.0.5148
```
NuGet Version: 4.7.0.5148
Attempting to build package from 'MyPackage.csproj'.
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '15.7.180.61344' from 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Enterprise\MSBuild\15.0\bin'. Use option -MSBuildVersion to force nuget to use a specific version of MSBuild.
Packing files from 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin'.
Using 'MyPackage.nuspec' for metadata.
Add file 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\MyPackage.dll' to package as 'lib\net462\MyPackage.dll'
Add file 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\MyPackage.xml' to package as 'lib\net462\MyPackage.xml'
Error NU5118: File 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\net40\MyPackage.dll' is not added because the package already contains file 'lib\net462\MyPackage.dll'
Error NU5118: File 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\net40\MyPackage.xml' is not added because the package already contains file 'lib\net462\MyPackage.xml'


Id: MyPackage
Version: 1.5.11589-Dev
Authors: SomeOne
Description: The common logging component.
Tags: MyPackage
Dependencies: 

Added file '[Content_Types].xml'.
Added file '_rels/.rels'.
Added file 'MyPackage.nuspec'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.dll'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.pdb'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.xml'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.dll'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.pdb'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.xml'.
Added file 'package/services/metadata/core-properties/1d7fa0645e124ec2ab9a1bced7054b89.psmdcp'.

Successfully created package 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\MyPackage.1.5.11589-Dev.nupkg'.
```

#### 4.8.0.5278
```
NuGet Version: 4.8.0.5278
Attempting to build package from 'MyPackage.csproj'.
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '15.7.180.61344' from 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Enterprise\MSBuild\15.0\bin'. Use option -MSBuildVersion to force nuget to use a specific version of MSBuild.
Packing files from 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin'.
Using 'MyPackage.nuspec' for metadata.
Add file 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\MyPackage.dll' to package as 'lib\net462\MyPackage.dll'
Add file 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\MyPackage.xml' to package as 'lib\net462\MyPackage.xml'
Error NU5118: File 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\net40\MyPackage.dll' is not added because the package already contains file 'lib\net462\MyPackage.dll'
Error NU5118: File 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\net40\MyPackage.xml' is not added because the package already contains file 'lib\net462\MyPackage.xml'


Id: MyPackage
Version: 1.5.11589-Dev
Authors: SomeOne
Description: The common logging component.
Tags: MyPackage
Dependencies: 

Added file '[Content_Types].xml'.
Added file '_rels/.rels'.
Added file 'MyPackage.nuspec'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.dll'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.pdb'.
Added file 'lib/net40/MyPackage.xml'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.dll'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.pdb'.
Added file 'lib/net462/MyPackage.xml'.
Added file 'package/services/metadata/core-properties/34306eea3da7466f8acf9275e92e3eb0.psmdcp'.

Successfully created package 'E:\Agent01\_work\404\s\InternalBin\MyPackage.1.5.11589-Dev.nupkg'.
```

## Question
1. Can that please be fixed?
2. Why is the earlier warning now an error but the creation is still successfull?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Test Failure] PackageReference Migrator menu was enabled incorrectly to all projects include C++ and .NET Core" (#7176) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev 5.0.0.5381
VS Version: D16.0stg 28002.3001
OS Version: Windows 10 RS4_Release 17134.1.180410-1804
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Create a C++ UWP template via VS.
2. Open PM UI of the project by right-clicking the project->Manage NuGet Packages… in Solution Explorer.
3. Install a package (e.g. “SampleCPlusPlusDevicePackage”) with “Packages.config” format.
4. Right-Click the “References” node or “packages.config” file.
## Expected
There should be no PackageReference Migrator menu since it not support for C++ project. 
## Actual
There is PackageReference Migrator menu showing and the “eligible for migration” warning dialog pop out after clicking the menu as below screenshot. 
![migratorenabledtoallprojects](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/43763866-692a6eea-9a1b-11e8-9a22-2fb2cd9493e7.png)

## Note
1.It repro on .NET Core projects which are already PackageReference.
2.It repro on D16.0stg 28002.3000+NuGet Client Dev 5.0.0.5375.
3.It didn't repro on D15.8 28002.00+NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-RTM\4.8.0.5377.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Signing:  incorrect URL check" (#7174) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):  All

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):  4.8

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:  4.7.  [This commit](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/commit/c4c7d2d3dd75604be94161a19c3c4e31dd4fb7d3) is the root cause.

[This](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/commit/c4c7d2d3dd75604be94161a19c3c4e31dd4fb7d3#diff-34ecb638a52dc1ba0229fc92f503b1c7R33) URL check is incorrect.  We should be checking `IRepositoryCertificateInfo.ContentUrl` instead.  The impact is that if nuget.org is registered as a package source with HTTP instead of HTTPS (i.e.:  http://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json), package restores will fail once nuget.org publishes repository signing information over V3.

CC @loic-sharma

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Fix VSIX build authoring issues - get VSSDK dependencies via a package rather than the resident VS installation" (#7175) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
For instance, its failing with interop type error on Agent: DDMBLDW133 -  https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=1923907&_a=summary&view=logs  
Same issue on another Agent: DDMBLDW133 - https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=1923848&_a=summary&view=logs 

```
src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.Tools\NuGetPackage.cs(86,13): Error CS1748: Cannot find the interop type that matches the embedded interop type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Shell.Interop.IVsToolboxItemProvider2'. Are you missing an assembly reference?
src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.Tools\NuGetPackage.cs(135,49): Error CS1748: Cannot find the interop type that matches the embedded interop type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Shell.Interop.IVsToolboxItemProvider2'. Are you missing an assembly reference?
src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.Tools\NuGetPackage.cs(197,45): Error CS1748: Cannot find the interop type that matches the embedded interop type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Shell.Interop.IVsToolboxItemProvider2'. Are you missing an assembly reference?
src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.Tools\NuGetPackage.cs(198,41): Error CS1748: Cannot find the interop type that matches the embedded interop type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Shell.Interop.IVsToolboxItemProvider2'. Are you missing an assembly reference?
src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.Tools\NuGetPackage.cs(662,34): Error CS1748: Cannot find the interop type that matches the embedded interop type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Shell.Interop.IVsToolboxItemProvider2'. Are you missing an assembly reference?
src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.Tools\NuGetPackage.cs(663,33): Error CS1748: Cannot find the interop type that matches the embedded interop type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Shell.Interop.IVsToolboxItemProvider2'. Are you missing an assembly reference?
Process 'msbuild.exe' exited with code '1'.
```

Comment from Andrew
```
15.6 did indeed change the VS SDK such that a base class (Package and/or AsyncPackage IIRC) implements additional interfaces that are defined in a new interop assembly. Given this broke your build, I expect you were getting your VS SDK reference assemblies from the VS installation instead of nuget. May I take this time to suggest that you revise your build authoring to acquire all your VS SDK dependencies from nuget instead to make yourself more resilient to changes on the build agent and ensure build reproducibility?
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Multi-targeted project fails to restore with a conditional NoWarn property group" (#6662) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Using VS2017 15.6.0, and [the attached solution](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1801280/20180311-nuget-nowarn-restore-failure.zip):

- Run git clean -fdx on the zipped repo (no restored graph must be present)
- Open VS2017 for the solution
- Notice the background restore does not start
- Try building, the error `Error occurred while restoring NuGet packages: The operation failed as details for project RestoreFailure could not be loaded.` appears at the beginning.

Commenting out this:
```xml
<PropertyGroup Condition=" '$(TargetFramework)' == 'net46'">
  <NoWarn>$(NoWarn);68</NoWarn>
</PropertyGroup>
```
or removing the condition makes the restore work properly.

Also note that the CLI restore does not have any issue restoring this project.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org" (#30) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The spec to **Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org** , is ready for **review**:

|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|:----------|:------------------|
|[Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Show-source-repository-information-for-packages-on-nuget.org) | https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4941 |

**Note**: This is a short term feature to just light up the repository information on nuget.org using the `<repository>`  metadata in the nuspec. We plan to revisit the detailed functionality, in future.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show outdated packages " (#27) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet `outdated` command spec to show outdated packages, is ready for **review**:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org accepts signed packages" (#26) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: Starting today May, 22nd 2018.  NuGet.org accepts signed packages. More information in the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180522/Introducing-signed-package-submissions.html)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org will only support MSA/AAD (to sign in) starting June 1st, 2018" (#25) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
